Dispute_Type: Judicial Review of Refugee Claim Decision
Legal_Issue: Lawfulness of rejection based on credibility and country conditions
Outcome: Decision set aside, case remanded for redetermination
Credibility_Assessment: Findings must be supported by concrete, cogent evidence; implausibility requires rigorous proof
Evidence_Type: Testimony, Country Conditions Reports, Religious Knowledge Assessment
Legal_Provision: Section 96 and 97 of IRPA (refugee protection provisions)
Basis_of_Claim: Persecution due to Christian faith in China
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility of applicant, interpretation of religious requirements, consistency with country conditions
Proceeding_Type: Refugee Protection Division hearing, followed by Federal Court judicial review
Application_Error: Overlooked contradictory evidence, misinterpreted religious knowledge requirements
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness, correctness for questions of law
Evidence_Ignored: Contradictory evidence regarding country conditions and religious practices
Legal_Standard: Credibility findings require cogent and compelling evidence; high threshold for finding implausibility
Application_Factor: Applicant's testimony consistency, knowledge of religion, plausibility in context of country conditions
Decision_Outcome: Original decision invalidated, referred back for reconsideration
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for factual findings, correctness for legal interpretations

Legal_Issue: Applicability of 'good faith' to sur place claims
Outcome: Claim dismissed due to legal error
Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions on truthfulness and refugee eligibility
Application_Error: Conflating 'good faith' with credibility instead of persecution risk
Evidence_Ignored: Potential for persecution due to making the claim
Legal_Standard: Good faith in the context of sur place claims
Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside, case remanded for redetermination

Violation_Type: Failure to properly assess risk of persecution
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 96, Section 97
Governing_Law: IRPA, Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, UN Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of persecution in China due to involvement with underground Christian church; non-leadership role; small group size; located in a liberal province
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to adequately address key evidence on doctrinal differences between state-sanctioned and underground churches
Evidence_Used: Testimony on religious practices, documentation on China's treatment of underground churches, location and size of religious group
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD ignored evidence regarding doctrinal differences between state and underground churches
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus was on RPD's interpretation of objective evidence
Decision_Outcome: RPD initially dismissed claim, finding no serious risk of persecution
Outcome: Judicial review granted; RPD decision overturned
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of refugee claim with proper assessment of religious persecution risk
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under IRPA and international refugee law
Decision_Rationale: RPD erred by dismissing doctrinal differences and equating lack of past imprisonment with absence of persecution risk
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Refugee Protection Division (RPD)

Violation_Type: Claiming refugee status without sufficient evidence of persecution
Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution for attending an unregistered church in China; RPD found oral evidence not credible and no documented incidents of persecution in Guangdong Province
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged misrepresentation or exaggeration of persecution risk
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of RPD decision on credibility and evidence assessment
Evidence_Used: Oral testimony, documentary evidence regarding religious persecution in China
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documented incidents of persecution in Guangdong; insufficient corroboration of personal claims
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant's oral evidence not credible
Outcome: Federal Court dismissed the application for judicial review
Relief_Sought: Overturning of RPD's negative decision on refugee claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution based on religion under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Decision_Rationale: Conclusion that there was no serious possibility of persecution was within the range of acceptable outcomes

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness and correct application of s. 19(1)(c.2) of the Immigration Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 19(1)(c.2)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Visa officer assessed credibility based on business ties and confidential information
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged false statements or omissions regarding criminal organization ties
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Ties to individuals and companies linked to triads
Crimes.Application_Factor: Prior notice and opportunity to respond provided

Crimes.Crime_Name: Reasonable grounds to believe involvement in criminal activity
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Interpretation of 'reasonable grounds' and 'member' under s. 19(1)(c.2)
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 19(1)(c.2)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Considered business links and confidential information
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On visa officer to establish reasonable grounds
Crimes.Legal_Rule: s. 19(1)(c.2) – inadmissibility for membership in criminal organization
Key_Evidence_Considered: Business relationships with known triad members
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Chiau denied ties and responded during interview

Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Whether applicant was given adequate opportunity to respond
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Confidential information not disclosed, but general concerns were communicated
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: No direct conviction, but alleged associations
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Reasonable grounds to believe membership in criminal organization
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Potential threat to public safety due to organized crime links
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Associations with triad-linked individuals and entities

Dispute_Type: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Legal_Issue: Assessment of applicant's work experience under Canadian Experience Class
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, Section 87.1 (Canadian Experience Class), Section 80(3) (Federal Skilled Worker Class)
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed, no costs awarded
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant provided conflicting information about job duties; explanations did not resolve inconsistencies
Evidence_Type: Employer confirmation of duties, applicant's statements
Legal_Provision: Section 87.1 IRPR, Section 80(3) IRPR
Basis_of_Claim: Claimed skilled work experience under NOC requirements
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Discrepancies between stated duties and employer-confirmed duties
Application_Error: Inconsistent reporting of job duties by applicant
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to officer's decision
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness of administrative decision, procedural fairness
Application_Factor: Work experience assessment under Canadian Experience Class
Document_Fraud: No explicit finding of document fraud, but false or inconsistent statements identified

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can a removal order be deferred due to child's best interests?
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA s. 48, Convention on the Rights of the Child
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to comply with immigration laws but has dependent children
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Family ties, care arrangements for children
Crimes.Application_Error: Removal officer did not adequately consider children's best interests
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Children’s lack of adequate care if parent removed
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Enforcement as soon as reasonably practicable under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Stay of removal pending assessment or judicial review

Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA, Convention on the Rights of the Child
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, has two young Canadian-born children
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Timing of H&C application and removal
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal immigration enforcement vs. provincial child welfare
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Children’s dependency, lack of custody resolution
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient consideration of children's welfare by officer
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: History of non-compliance but genuine care for children
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal based on humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the child under IRPA and international law
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Risk of irreparable harm to children outweighs immediate removal

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with reporting conditions
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Enforcement of reporting obligations and removal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Must removal officers consider children's best interests before removal?
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA s. 48, Convention on the Rights of the Child
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review and motion for stay
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Children would be left without adequate care
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show irreparable harm and serious issue
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Removal must consider short-term best interests of children
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure of removal officer to assess child welfare
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Pending full assessment or judicial review
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Dependency of Canadian-born children on applicant
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA and international human rights standards

Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant has a fairly arguable case to justify judicial review of the PRRA officer's decision denying humanitarian and compassionate grounds for permanent residence
Governing_Law: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Outcome: Application for leave denied
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to provide supporting evidence for claimed personalized risk
Evidence_Type: Lack of supporting evidence for compulsory military service risk in Albania
Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds for permanent residence based on risk of compulsory military service in Albania
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to demonstrate a fairly arguable case for judicial review
Application_Error: Failure to provide sufficient evidence to support the claim
Application_Factor: Personalized risk due to compulsory military service
Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed; no serious question raised
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness not specified; assessed under fairly arguable threshold for leave

Dispute_Type: Visa denial based on insufficient documentation and likelihood of departure
Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer's decision was patently unreasonable
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 72(1)
Outcome: Decision quashed, judicial review granted, case remitted for re-determination
Credibility_Assessment: Concerns about applicant's ties to Pakistan and financial proof
Evidence_Type: International travel history, familial ties, financial documentation
Legal_Provision: subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Basis_of_Claim: Perceived weak ties to home country and insufficient financial documentation
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Patent unreasonableness due to generalizations and irrelevant considerations
Application_Error: Reliance on son's out-of-status situation, disregard of valid travel history
Application_Factor: Ties to home country, financial standing, intent to depart Canada

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Chen met the residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Judge found Mr. Chen's evidence incomplete and misleading
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to demonstrate physical presence in Canada for 1,095 days within four years
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Applicant must prove physical presence for 1,095 days

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Chen provided sufficient and credible evidence to meet the residency requirement
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Judge found explanations implausible and unverifiable

Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Discrepancies in documentation and lack of verifiability
Crimes.Application_Error: Submission of misleading and incomplete evidence
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Quantitative or qualitative test for residency
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Burden of proof on applicant with credible evidence
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Denial of citizenship due to insufficient evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with a removal order

Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of clean hands, failure to comply with removal order

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Did the Officer commit a reviewable error based on the evidence presented?
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Officer commit a reviewable error based on the evidence presented?
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Insufficient evidence of hardship, lack of proof of disproportionate hardship upon return
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Disregard for immigration laws, insufficient evidence, lack of clean hands

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Harkat has established a material change in circumstances warranting reconsideration of his release
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Harkat demonstrated unexplained delays, shifting evidentiary burden to the Ministers

Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Strict conditions can mitigate potential risks
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Whether release poses danger to national security or any person

Crimes.Application_Factor: Demonstrated delay in removal and potential for prolonged detention
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Release under stringent monitoring and restrictions

Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat to national security if released without conditions
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Past involvement with terrorism raises security concerns
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Security certificate issued based on reasonable grounds
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Subject of a security certificate alleging engagement in terrorism
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Confidential evidence presented during judicial review
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Use of confidential information in assessing danger
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Concerns over credibility mitigated by strict release conditions
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Length of detention and lack of imminent removal
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Balance of probabilities applied in administrative context
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Subsection 84(2), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Detention and release under security certificate
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Conditional release with stringent terms to mitigate risk

Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Threat to national security due to association
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Ongoing concern based on security certificate
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Prolonged detention due to procedural delays
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Affiliation and support for a terrorist group
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Based on confidential intelligence and judicial assessment
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Reliance on non-disclosed evidence in security certificate
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Risk assessed as manageable under strict conditions
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Lack of recent activity, compliance history, and monitoring feasibility
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Preponderance of evidence standard in administrative detention context
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Subsection 84(2), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of continued detention under security certificate
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Conditional release authorized with electronic monitoring and movement restrictions

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to demonstrate ties to home country

Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) and IRPR
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant is a Nigerian national applying for a work permit; has family and marital ties in Nigeria but plans to reside in Canada for an extended period
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to demonstrate intent to leave Canada after authorized stay
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of strong ties compelling return to Nigeria
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible but insufficient to overcome socio-economic incentives to remain in Canada
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Leave to remain in Canada under work permit
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Socio-economic incentives to stay in Canada outweighed familial ties in Nigeria
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations

Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Visa officer relied on interview notes and application documents
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant’s indirect supervision experience not equivalent to direct care

Legal_Issue: Breach of principles of natural justice

Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to consider unique circumstances of each applicant
Application_Error: Dismissal based on common factors without individual analysis
Decision_Outcome: Remanded to a different panel for new hearing

Crimes.Crime_Name: False or misleading information in personal information form (PIF)
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred by failing to consider reasonable explanations for discrepancies in Mr. Ahmed's PIF
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision quashed and remitted for reconsideration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board found credibility concerns due to PIF discrepancies but failed to analyze provided explanations
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal Information Form (PIF), oral testimony, applicant's explanations
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 101(1)(a) of the IRPA regarding false statements
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Omissions and inconsistencies in PIF regarding family member’s illness and travel history
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to address plausible explanations for discrepancies
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of applicant's explanations for inconsistencies
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Applicant's explanation about learning of sister’s illness from a friend and lack of entry/exit controls in Pakistan
Crimes.Legal_Standard: The Board must engage with reasonable explanations even if it ultimately rejects them
Crimes.Application_Factor: Presence of omissions in mandatory government form (PIF)
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Negative credibility finding leading to rejection of claim

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in disregarding reasonable explanations for discrepancies in Mr. Ahmed's testimony
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Testimonial inconsistencies regarding knowledge of family events and police inquiries
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Original claim dismissed; decision quashed on judicial review
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish credibility and basis for protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Inconsistencies between testimony and documented facts
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Board must analyze all reasonable explanations provided by applicant
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Not determined – case remitted for reconsideration
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Oral testimony, family circumstances, police interaction claims
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA and Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Mr. Ahmed provided contextual explanations for discrepancies
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Oral testimony, personal explanations, hearsay accounts
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Allowance of refugee claim or order for reconsideration
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted; case remitted to differently constituted Board

Legal_Issue: Delay in filing refugee claim and credibility of fear

Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness, misinterpretation of evidence

Basis_of_Claim: Inconsistencies in ages, identities, and relationships

Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious criminality under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Testimony found unreliable by the tribunal
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Risk of reoffending and lack of rehabilitation outweighed humanitarian considerations such as family ties.

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration appeal involving criminal conduct and probation violations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the tribunal reasonably assessed risk and humanitarian factors

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Band Council's decision to withhold loan payments is reviewable under judicial review principles
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: The impugned BCR relates to a commercial loan agreement, a private law matter
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish standing and amenability to judicial review

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Application_Facts: Plaintiffs overstayed visas and applied under H&C program
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant past status, compliant present integration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Generally credible despite initial violations

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Improper denial based on 'organized plan' and misrepresentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Misrepresentation found but mitigated by humanitarian factors
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Establishment in Canada and humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Jurisdictional error in rigid guideline application
Crimes.Application_Error: Denial based solely on 'organized plan' without H&C assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Integration, employment, family ties in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Statutory discretion prevails over restrictive guidelines
Crimes.Application_Factor: Prior misrepresentation and mode of entry

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to depart after visa expiration
Crimes.Application_Facts: Plaintiffs remained beyond authorized stay and applied for permanent residency
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged participation in organized entry scheme
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible claimants despite immigration violations
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Guidelines must not override statutory intent

Dispute_Type: Ownership and mortgage rights in vessel arrest
Legal_Issue: Can F.C. Yachts Ltd. bring an action in rem against yachts it legally and beneficially owns?
Governing_Law: Section 43(3) of the Federal Courts Act
Procedural_Stage: Motion to set aside warrant of arrest
Evidence_Assessment: Contract confirming F.C. Yachts as legal and beneficial owner; Splash Holdings as mortgagee only
Decision_Outcome: Warrant of arrest set aside; actions in rem dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On claimant (F.C. Yachts) to establish right to in rem action
Credibility_Factor: Undisputed ownership documentation and contractual terms
Legal_Rule: An action in rem requires the ship to be beneficially owned by the person who was the owner at the time the cause of action arose
Standard_of_Review: Statutory interpretation and application of procedural requirements under admiralty law
Grounds_for_Claim: Unpaid progress payments for yacht construction
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed: F.C. Yachts cannot arrest its own vessels
Key_Evidence_Considered: Ownership contract; mortgage agreement; absence of ownership transfer
Legal_Framework: Federal Courts Act, Canadian admiralty law
Defendant_Response: Splash Holdings moved to set aside the arrest, asserting lack of jurisdiction due to ownership
Remedy_Requested: Action in rem, arrest of yachts
Outcome: Motion granted; warrant set aside; costs awarded to Splash Holdings Ltd.
Legal_Provision: Section 43(3), Federal Courts Act
Authority: Federal Court of Canada, Harrington J.

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Legal_Provision_Involved: Rule 221(1)(a) of the Rules of Civil Procedure
Outcome: Motion to strike granted
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged breach of procedural fairness by CSC representatives
Legal_Framework: Tort law, specifically the tort of misfeasance in public office
Decision_Outcome: Statement of Claim dismissed without leave to amend
Institutional_Action: CSC representatives' conduct challenged for unlawfulness and bad faith
Individual_Status_or_Claim: Plaintiff claiming damages due to alleged misconduct
Legal_Provision: Tort of misfeasance in public office requires deliberate and unlawful conduct with awareness of unlawfulness and likelihood of harm
Victim_Basis: Plaintiff alleging harm from public officer misconduct

Application_Facts: Applicant's citizenship application was denied due to alleged failure to meet residency requirements
Residency_Compliance: Residency requirement not properly assessed by judge
Procedural_Issue: Judge failed to consider Re Koo factors
Failed to communicate concerns to applicant
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider required factors from Re Koo
Outcome: Decision found unreasonable
Decision_Rationale: Judge did not apply Re Koo factors, used irrelevant evidence, and violated natural justice

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of CRA's decision to dismiss ITPR application due to lateness
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant faced barriers such as being on leave and lack of access to resources
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate unreasonableness of administrative decision
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's explanation for delay considered credible
Legal_Rule: Reasonableness standard applies; decision must be justified, transparent, and intelligible
Grounds_for_Claim: Misapplication of discretion, failure to consider individual circumstances, procedural unfairness
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim succeeded on grounds of administrative unreasonableness
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of delays, applicant's personal circumstances, non-mandatory nature of time limit
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, principles of procedural fairness, statutory interpretation
Defendant_Response: CRA strictly applied time limit without flexibility or contextual consideration
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, applicant's affidavit explaining delay
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, setting aside of CRA decision, reconsideration of application
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; CRA decision set aside; application remitted for reconsideration
Legal_Provision: Time limits under ITPR program (non-mandatory), Federal Courts Act provisions

Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer's decision on education points was unreasonable and breached fairness or discretion requirements
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant claimed 18 years of study; Officer awarded points for 13 years due to unverified primary school years and unexplained gap in O-Level studies; additional evidence submitted post-decision did not change outcome
Decision_Outcome: Officer’s decision upheld; application for permanent residency refused due to insufficient points
Burden_of_Proof: On Applicant to demonstrate error in Officer’s assessment
Credibility_Factor: Unsubstantiated claim of 10 primary school years and unexplained educational gap affected credibility
Legal_Rule: Applicants must score at least 67 points under IRPA; education points based on verifiable years of study and credentials; Officers may substitute evaluations if better reflecting economic potential
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged miscalculation of education years, breach of procedural fairness, improper use of discretion
Outcome_on_Merits: No error found in Officer’s decision; challenge dismissed
Key_Evidence_Considered: Educational records, credential assessments, settlement funds information
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) and associated Regulations
Defendant_Response: Officer provided rationale for point allocation and exercised discretion considering settlement ability
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (educational transcripts, evaluations), post-decision submissions
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Legal_Provision: IRPA sections related to Federal Skilled Worker Program and point assessment criteria

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), section 97(1)
Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
International refugee law (1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees)
Application_Facts: Three Tamil brothers claimed refugee status in Canada, citing fear of persecution due to perceived LTTE links; claimed changed country conditions in Sri Lanka (sur place claim)
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to reasonably assess sur place claim
Speculated without evidence regarding return to Sri Lanka
Evidence_Used: Amnesty International report on human rights conditions in Sri Lanka
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board ignored key evidence (Amnesty International report)
Relied on unwarranted speculation instead of evidence
Decision_Outcome: Board rejected the applicants' sur place refugee claim
Outcome: Federal Court allowed judicial review
Decision set aside
Remanded for redetermination by a different RPD member
Relief_Sought: Recognition as refugees based on sur place claims
Protection from removal to Sri Lanka
Decision_Rationale: Board's decision was unreasonable due to failure to consider all relevant evidence and engagement in speculation about post-removal scrutiny in Sri Lanka

Legal_Provision_Violated: paragraph 41(1)(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Application_Facts: Applicant delayed filing due to depression; medical evidence provided but investigator concluded disability did not prevent timely filing
Procedural_Issue: Request for time extension under paragraph 41(1)(e)
Decision_Outcome: Commission refused to extend time limit
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed
Relief_Sought: Extension of time to file human rights complaint
Legal_Standard_Applied: Commission may extend time if deemed appropriate under paragraph 41(1)(e)
Decision_Rationale: Commission reviewed all materials and found no basis to extend time; decision not patently unreasonable

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 72 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution in Pakistan due to political opinions and gender; provided inconsistent evidence including incorrect legal codes; delayed refugee claim; lacked credible evidence of subjective fear
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistent statements, including incorrect legal codes cited by applicant
Procedural_Issue: Delay in claiming refugee status; credibility assessed as implausible by tribunal
Evidence_Used: Tribunal's assessment of applicant's testimony and documentary inconsistencies
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence supporting subjective fear; contradictions in narrative
Credibility_Assessment: Tribunal found applicant's account implausible; no perverse or capricious finding identified by court
Outcome: Application for judicial review denied
Relief_Sought: Overturning of tribunal's dismissal of refugee claim
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with deference to tribunal on credibility unless decision is patently unreasonable or based on error of law
Decision_Rationale: Tribunal's findings were reasonable; applicant's story contained contradictions and lacked credible evidence of fear; delay undermined claim; no legal error identified
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court (on judicial review)

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in finding residency compliance
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Respondent's credibility questioned due to inconsistent statements
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Misrepresentation in application affecting residency claim
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistent reporting of absences and potential misrepresentation
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review under s. 14(5) of the Citizenship Act and s. 21 of the Federal Courts Act
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose all absences from Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Discrepancies in absence reporting and passport evidence not adequately addressed
Crimes.Application_Factor: Accuracy and completeness of residency information

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the respondent met the 1095-day physical presence requirement
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Appeal under s. 14(5) of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conflicting evidence on absences and passport indicating unreported travel
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove physical presence for 1095 days
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Inconsistent reporting affecting reliability of claims
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Applicant must demonstrate compliance with residency requirement
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet statutory residency requirement
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Citizenship Act and Federal Courts Act

Application_Facts: Applicant submitted NOC from CARA; officer deemed it fraudulent without further inquiry despite conflicting evidence
Procedural_Issue: Officer failed to investigate CARA's response and consider applicant submissions
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of investigation into conflicting evidence regarding NOC authenticity
Credibility_Assessment: NOC deemed fraudulent without adequate assessment
Outcome: Judicial review allowed
Remedy_Sought: Remand to a different officer for reconsideration
Decision_Rationale: Officer breached duty of procedural fairness by not investigating conflicting evidence and applicant's submissions

Legal_Provision_Violated: Residence requirements under the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Ms. Huang applied for Canadian citizenship but had inconsistencies in her evidence regarding physical presence in Canada; she spent significant time outside Canada and provided conflicting information about her residence.
Residency_Compliance: Not met – judge found insufficient proof of centralized mode of living, regular/normally/customarily residing in Canada, or sufficient physical presence
Misrepresentation_Element: Potential misrepresentation due to inconsistent evidence on residency
Procedural_Issue: Allegation of procedural unfairness in the assessment by the citizenship judge
Evidence_Used: Travel records, duration and frequency of absences from Canada, statements about ties to Canada, employment, family connections
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inconsistencies in Ms. Huang’s testimony and documentation regarding her presence in Canada
Credibility_Assessment: Negative – the judge questioned the reliability of Ms. Huang’s claims about her residence patterns
Outcome: Appeal dismissed by the Federal Court
Relief_Sought: Overturning of the citizenship judge's decision and approval of citizenship application
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the citizenship judge’s decision
Decision_Rationale: The citizenship judge reasonably applied the Koo test as permitted by jurisprudence; factual findings on residence were supported by evidence; no error in law or procedure established
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Commission (via citizenship judge), Federal Court on appeal

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Failure to analyze subjective fear of persecution before assessing state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not conducted by tribunal
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Alleged threats from FARC in Ecuador
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Subjective fear must precede state protection analysis
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Credibility and plausibility of applicant's fear
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Subjective fear analysis required prior to state protection evaluation

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Failure to assess subjective fear before determining state protection availability
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Lack of credibility analysis regarding fear of persecution
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish subjective fear
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Threats from FARC not assessed for credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Subjective fear must be evaluated before state protection
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Not applicable – administrative tribunal decision under review

Crimes.Violation_Type: Unauthorized stay in the U.S. and illegal entry into Canada
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant fled Ecuador, overstayed U.S. visa, entered Canada illegally
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant with immigration status in both U.S. and Canada
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Potential failure to disclose prior unlawful stay
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Sequence of refugee claim analysis under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Alleged FARC threats and flight path
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No credibility assessment of applicant's fear
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not performed by Refugee Protection Division
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Procedural unfairness due to omitted fear analysis
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Refugee Protection Division, Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to seek asylum in the United States
Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to pursue available asylum protection in a safe third country
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Safe Third Country Agreement between Canada and the U.S.
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in U.S. illegally after fleeing Ecuador, did not apply for asylum there
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Potential omission or justification of failure to claim asylum in U.S.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Tribunal failed to assess subjective fear before evaluating state protection
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Applicability of state protection analysis sequence
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No analysis of credibility or plausibility of fear
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not conducted
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Mandatory sequence: subjective fear before state protection

Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant's motion for an extension of time to file for judicial review can be granted under s. 82.1(5) of the Immigration Act
Procedural_Stage: Motion for extension of time; Judicial review application
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient details provided about conviction or Minister's decision; reliance on solicitor's affidavit instead of personal testimony
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant failed to meet burden by not showing special reasons or good case on the merits
Credibility_Factor: Lack of personal affidavit from applicant affects credibility
Legal_Rule: Section 82.1(5) requires 'special reasons', a good case on the merits, and procedural compliance for extension
Grounds_for_Claim: Extension of time beyond 15-day limit for filing judicial review
Outcome_on_Merits: No determination made due to procedural deficiencies
Legal_Framework: Immigration and refugee protection law; procedural rules for judicial review
Remedy_Requested: Extension of time to file for leave and judicial review
Outcome: Motion dismissed; originating motion for leave and judicial review denied
Legal_Provision: s. 82.1(5), Immigration Act

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Legal_Provision_Involved: Article 1(F)(a) of the Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Outcome: Exclusion from refugee protection
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution by Mexican police for refusing corruption
Legal_Framework: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Targeted_Group: Civilians subjected to systematic abuse by police
State_Protection_Assessment: Internal flight alternative considered available in Monterrey
Risk_Factor: Association with a repressive state apparatus
Credibility: Credible evidence of complicity based on conduct and awards
Legal_Provision: Article 1(F)(a)
State_Protection_Adequacy: Deemed adequate due to availability of internal flight alternative
Victim_Basis: Civilians subject to torture and false imprisonment

Sub_Crime_Type: False imprisonment as part of crimes against humanity
Aggravating_Factors: High confession rates linked to coercion
Criminality_Severity: High – part of systematic attacks on civilians
Risk_Assessment: Ongoing risk due to institutional tolerance
Targeted_Individual: Detainees used to achieve high conviction rates
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to disengage despite knowledge
Legal_Provision: Article 1(F)(a) of the Convention

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Legal_Provision_Involved: Article 1(F)(a) of the Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Outcome: Exclusion from refugee protection
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution by Mexican police for refusing corruption
Legal_Framework: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Risk_Factor: Active participation in or tolerance of torture
Credibility: Credible evidence of complicity based on role and recognition
Legal_Provision: Article 1(F)(a)
State_Protection_Adequacy: Deemed adequate due to internal flight possibility

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in determining the applicants were not Convention refugees or persons in need of protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Fear not objectively well-founded; insufficient evidence to prove lack of state protection or internal flight alternative
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Persecution fears from a gang and a municipal employee in Venezuela
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Availability of state protection and internal flight alternative
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified as ignored; rather, evidence was deemed insufficient
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonable possibility standard, not balance of probabilities
Crimes.Application_Factor: Failure to prove lack of state protection or impossibility of internal relocation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failing to report threats to police
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Section 97, IRPA (persons in need of protection)
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Extortion by gang and harassment by municipal employee
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Denial of refugee status by IRB
Crimes.Credibility: Partially undermined due to lack of reporting

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to provide sufficient evidence to rebut state protection presumption
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 101(1)(a), IRPA (burden of proof on claimant)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Anonymous police complaint without identifying details
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Jurisdiction of Federal Court over IRB decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of detail and verification in anonymous complaint
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Undermined due to inconsistencies
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Recognition as refugee or protected person
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of question or overturning of decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Clear and convincing evidence to rebut state protection
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Anonymous complaint insufficient to prove lack of state protection

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Repetition of demands, abuse of public office
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: No physical harm reported, limited geographic threat
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Moderate to high, depending on enforcement context
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Personalized based on prior employment dispute
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Partially compromised by lack of corroboration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Questioned due to inconsistencies and lack of reporting
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA sections related to refugee determination

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Legal_Provision_Involved: s. 18.1(4) of the Federal Court Act
Outcome: Motion to introduce fresh evidence dismissed
Credibility: Applicant failed to submit available evidence in time
